title: 109_hr6062
content: The "Community Development Investment Enhancements Act of 2006" enhances the authority for national banks to make community development investments. The "Community Development Investment Enhancements Act of 2006" increases the investment limits for national and state member banks to 15 percent, up from 10 percent, for each investment made directly or by subsidiaries. The investment limits for national and state member banks have been increased to 15 percent from 10 percent for each investment made directly or by subsidiaries. Investments by federal savings associations are authorized to promote the public welfare. Federal savings associations can make investments to promote the public welfare, specifically targeting low- and moderate-income communities through housing, services, and job opportunities. Investments can be made directly or by acquiring interests in companies engaged in such activities. The Director establishes limits on the amount any savings association can invest in a project and the total investment amount allowed. No investment can subject a Federal savings association to unlimited liability. The Director sets limits on savings association investments, with a flexible aggregate investment cap based on capital stock and surplus. The Director can allow investments exceeding the limit if it poses no significant risk to the deposit insurance fund. The aggregate investment of a savings association is capped at 15% of capital stock and 15% of unimpaired surplus. The savings association's investments are not subject to limitations on quality, and each investment must adhere to specific standards and limitations. The savings association's investments are not subject to limitations on quality, and each investment must adhere to specific standards and limitations. Section 5(c)(3)(A) of the Home Owners' Loan Act is amended to repeal a provision regarding investments made by a savings association and its subsidiaries. The House of Representatives passed the bill on September 27, 2006. Karen L. Haas is the Clerk.
